title: Part B

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the percent coverage of dead vegetation in the unburned plot compared to the plot burned most recently, such as any of the following:

· There is a higher percentage of dead vegetation ground cover in the plot that was burned most recently (two years before the data were collected).

· There is a lower percentage of dead vegetation ground cover in the unburned plot compared to the plot that was burned most recently.

· The percent cover of dead vegetation in the unburned plot is close to 0% compared to the most recently burned plot at 42%–45%. Carbon cycling in the savanna will occur at a higher rate than in the tundra because there are warmer temperatures.

The response describes the percent coverage of dead vegetation in the unburned plot compared to the plot burned most recently, such as any of the following:

· There is a higher percentage of dead vegetation ground cover in the plot that was burned most recently (two years before the data were collected).

· There is a lower percentage of dead vegetation ground cover in the unburned plot compared to the plot that was burned most recently.

· The percent cover of dead vegetation in the unburned plot is close to 0% compared to the most recently burned plot at 42% – 45%. Carbon cycling in the savanna will occur at a higher rate than in the tundra because there are warmer temperatures.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim based on evidence in the graph to support or refute the hypothesis that in the Alaskan tundra study area, sedges and grasses will dominate the landscape in later succession stages, such as any of the following:

· The hypothesis is refuted because lichens (50% ground cover) dominate the unburned plot, not sedges and grasses (17% ground cover).

· The hypothesis is refuted because sedges and grasses do not dominate in the unburned plot or later succession stage such as 46 years.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe how lichen could be used as an environmental indicator species to monitor emission levels from a power plant that is using a nonrenewable energy source such as the following:

· Coal-burning power plants can release sulfur dioxide into the air. If lichen populations decline in an area, it could indicate that excessive sulfur dioxide was being emitted from coal-burning power plants.

The response describes how lichen could be used as an environmental indicator species to monitor emission levels from a power plant that is using a nonrenewable energy source such as the following:

· Coal-burning power plants can release sulfur dioxide into the air. If lichen populations decline in an area, it could indicate that excessive sulfur dioxide was being emitted from coal-burning power plants.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify the hypothesis of the investigation, such as any of the following:

· The average thaw depth will decrease overall as the number of years since the last fire increases, or the average thaw depth will increase overall as the number of years since the last fire decreases.

· The average surface organic thickness will increase overall as the number of years since the last fire increases, or the average surface organic thickness will decrease overall as the number of years since the last fire decreases.

· There is no relationship between the average thaw depth or average surface organic thickness and the number of years since the last fire.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the relationship between average thaw depth and average surface organic thickness, such as any of the following:

· As the average thaw depth increased overall, the average surface organic thickness increased overall.

· As the average thaw depth decreased overall, the average surface organic thickness decreased overall.

· The average thaw depth and the average surface organic thickness are directly related.

· As the average thaw depth decreased overall, the average surface organic thickness decreased overall.

· The average thaw depth and the average surface organic thickness are directly related.

title: Part I
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why the scientist would test for pH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabchacaqGibaaaa@39B7@ levels in the soil in the study plots, such as any of the following:

· Most soil nutrients are more soluble in slightly acidic soils. pH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabchacaqGibaaaa@39B7@ is a measure of acidity and would therefore indicate if it would be easy for soil nutrients to be taken up by plants or a soil amendment would need to be added to make the soil more acidic.

· Plants are adapted to growing at specific levels of acidity in soil. pH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabchacaqGibaaaa@39B7@ is a measure of acidity and a wildfire may alter the soil’s pH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabchacaqGibaaaa@39B7@ to the point that it exceeds a plant’s range of tolerance and some plants would be unable to grow.

· Typically, after a wildfire the pH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabchacaqGibaaaa@39B7@ of soil increases. A high pH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabchacaqGibaaaa@39B7@ may indicate a more recent fire.

title: Part J
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim about the relative soil nutrient levels in sandy soils compared to clay soils, such as any of the following:

· Soils with high percentages of clay tend to hold more water and nutrients than sandy soils so sandy soils would have lower nutrient levels than clay soils.

· Soils with high percentages of clay have negatively charged sites on clay particles (high cation exchange capacity) that help them hold positively charged nutrient ions. As a result, clay soils have higher nutrient levels than sandy soils.

· Soils with high percentages of clay have a higher surface area than sandy soils. As a result, clay soils have higher nutrient levels than sandy soils.

The response makes a claim about the relative soil nutrient levels in sandy soils compared to clay soils, such as one of the following:

· Soils with high percentages of clay tend to hold more water and nutrients than sandy soils so sandy soils would have lower nutrient levels than clay soils.

· Soils with high percentages of clay have negatively charged sites on clay particles (high cation exchange capacity) that help them hold positively charged nutrient ions. As a result, clay soils have higher nutrient levels than sandy soils.

· Soils with high percentages of clay have a higher surface area than sandy soils. As a result, clay soils have higher nutrient levels than sandy soils.
